text: Here , we have shown that the <extra_id_0> Tat <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - dependent transcriptional activation of a number of pro-inflammatory genes required the assembly of <extra_id_0> Tat <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> with <extra_id_0> p65 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> at the NF-kappaB enhancer together with the displacement of <extra_id_0> IkappaB-alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( Figure 5 ) .

text: Thus , in the set of distinct NF-kappaB - responsive genes , <extra_id_0> Tat <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> acted as a component of the transcriptional initiation complex , which is consistent with previous reports on <extra_id_0> Tat <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> promoting the transcription via DNA motifs ( 72 , 73 ) .
event: <extra_id_0> <extra_id_1>

text: Overproduction of pro-inflammatory cytokines is considered a major mechanism of immune deregulation ( 26 ) and neuron dysfunction in AIDS ( 74 , 75 ) .
event: <extra_id_0> <extra_id_1>

text: In this scenario , inhibition of NF-kappaB activity could lead to a therapeutic strategy for counteracting the abnormal production of pro-inflammatory cytokines and chemokines in HIV-1 infection .
event: <extra_id_0> <extra_id_1>

text: NF-kappaB inhibitors , such as anti-oxidants , proteasome and IKK inhibitors , significantly reduced the HIV-1 replication and the associated inflammatory response ( 76 , 77 ) ; however , these NF-kappaB inhibitors acted indiscriminately in both HIV-1-infected and uninfected cells .
event: <extra_id_0> <extra_id_1>
